## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Lucy, Parker Solar Probe)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-08-30T20:47:34Z
## Message ID: 20240830-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-08-30T12:53Z.

Estimated speed: ~573 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 30 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -56/-5 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-08-30T12:53:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Lucy and Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Lucy at 2024-09-02T10:24Z and Parker Solar Probe at 2024-09-01T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2024-08-30T12:53:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240830_185600_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240830_185600_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240830_185600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240830_185600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_PSP_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240830_185600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Lucy_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2024-08-30T12:53:00-CME-001) is likely associated with M3.8 flare with ID 2024-08-30T12:13:00-FLR-001 from Active Region 3806 (S12E55) which peaked at 2024-08-30T12:20Z.


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 21, 2024 - August 27, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-08-28T21:33:45Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-08-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-08-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240828-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity varied between low and moderate levels during this reporting period with 18 M-class flares and 5 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-08-23T02:00Z would reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-26T14:22Z (plus minus 7 hours) with possible Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notifications 20240823-AL-002 and 20240824-AL-001). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 40 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2024-08-26T07:38Z and 2024-08-26T21:37Z (average arrival 2024-08-26T13:50Z) for 45% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is an 89% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor). Full details of the modeled event are available here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/Detailed_results_20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066.txt (see notification 20240824-AL-001). The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 around 2024-08-27T07:33Z (see notification 20240827-AL-001). The arrival of this CME may have also been detected at STEREO A around 2024-08-26T17:00Z. Analysis of this arrival signature is ongoing.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-08-22T06:53Z  OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-08-24T00:00Z (glancing blow) and Solar Orbiter at 2024-08-24T15:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240822-AL-001).
2024-08-22T15:09Z  OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-08-23T23:53Z and Solar Orbiter at 2024-08-24T13:30Z (see notification 20240823-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-08-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-09-03T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently eleven numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13796 (S04W64) and 13800 (S27W45) exhibited notable flaring activity during the reporting period and may continue to be the source of significant solar activity as they traverse the Earth-facing disk. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between below minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. An enhancement in geomagnetic activity was observed during the synoptic period 2024-08-28T00:00Z-03:00Z in which Kp reached 5.67 due to the ongoing arrival of the S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-08-23T02:00Z detected at L1 around 2024-08-27T07:33Z (see notifications 20240828-AL-001 and 20240828-AL-002). A small coronal hole structure centered around S00W35 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-08-29.

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 5.67 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2024-08-28T00:00Z to 2024-08-28T03:00Z. 

The storm is caused by Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-08-27T07:33:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240827-AL-001) which is associated with the arrival of CME with ID 2024-08-23T02:00:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240823-AL-002, 20240824-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-08-28T00:00:00-GST-001.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, Mars, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-08-24T12:17:39Z
## Message ID: 20240824-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2024-08-23T02:00:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20240823-AL-002). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A and Mars. For 40 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2024-08-25T20:53Z and 2024-08-26T23:55Z (average arrival 2024-08-26T10:49Z) for 97% of simulations.
- Mars between about 2024-08-28T02:53Z and 2024-08-28T02:53Z (average arrival 2024-08-28T02:53Z) for 2% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2024-08-26T07:38Z and 2024-08-26T21:37Z (average arrival 2024-08-26T13:50Z) for 45% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is an 89% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066_arrival_Mars.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066_Mars_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2024-08-23T02:00:00-CME-001) is also predicted to impact at Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-25T12:19Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20240823-AL-002).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-23_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066/Detailed_results_20240823_020000_ncmes1_sims40_LAHAINA066.txt
###

## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-08-23T02:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~461 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 38 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 31/-2 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-08-23T02:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, and Mars (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-25T12:19Z, STEREO A at 2024-08-26T08:30Z, and the flank of the CME may reach Mars at 2024-08-28T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-26T14:22Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare and 19 M-class flares, 3 O-type CMEs, and 20 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-08-14T08:23Z would reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-17T05:10Z (plus minus 7 hours) with possible Kp index 6-8 (moderate to severe) (see notifications 20240814-AL-005 and 20240815-AL-001). The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 around 2024-08-17T13:29Z (see notification 20240817-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 6.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 6.67 occurred during the synoptic period 2024-08-17T15:00Z to 2024-08-17T18:00Z (see notifications 20240817-AL-004 and 20240817-AL-005). This strong geomagnetic storm was associated with an interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-08-17T13:29Z (see notification 20240817-AL-001) that was likely caused by the arrival of C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-08-14T08:23Z (see notifications 20240814-AL-005 and 20240815-AL-001). During the reporting period, simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-08-17T18:05Z (see notifications 20240817-AL-002 and 20240817-AL-003).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this reporting period due to geomagnetic activity described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-08-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-08-27T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently eleven numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13790 (S13W07) and 13796 (S04E29) exhibited notable flaring during the reporting period and may continue to be the source of significant solar activity as they traverse the Earth-facing disk during the outlook period. Active Region 13784, the source of one X-class flare during the reporting period, rotated beyond the western limb of the Earth-facing disk on 2024-08-21 and may be the source of far-sided solar activity during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Two coronal holes structures centered around N15W45 and N38W22 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-08-21 and 2024-08-23, respectively.

## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6.67 (strong) during the synoptic period 2024-08-17T15:00Z to 2024-08-17T18:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-08-17T13:29:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240817-AL-001) which is likely associated with the arrival of CME with ID 2024-08-14T08:23:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240814-AL-005 and 20240815-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2024-08-14T08:23:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20240814-AL-005). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 32 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2024-08-16T21:58Z and 2024-08-17T06:28Z (average arrival 2024-08-17T03:23Z) for 53% of simulations.

Additionally, the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2024-08-16T22:03Z and 2024-08-17T09:39Z (average arrival 2024-08-17T04:36Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 76% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-14_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065/20240814_082300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-14_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065/20240814_082300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-14_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065/20240814_082300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-14_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065/20240814_082300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-14_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065/20240814_082300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2024-08-14T08:23:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-16T09:30Z (plus minus 7 hours) and a glancing blow at Lucy 2024-08-18T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20240814-AL-005).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2024-08-14_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065/Detailed_results_20240814_082300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA065.txt

Geomagnetic activity was at severe levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 8 during the reporting period. The geomagnetic storm lasted from 2024-08-12T00:00Z to 2024-08-13T00:00Z, with Kp values ranging from 5.67 to 8. The highest value of Kp = 8 occurred during the synoptic period 2024-08-12T12:00Z-15:00Z (see notifications 20240812-AL-002, 20240812-AL-003, 20240812-AL-004, 20240812-AL-005, and 20240812-AL-006). This severe geomagnetic storm was associated with an interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-08-11T19:53Z that was likely caused by the combined arrival of two S-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C3 at 2024-08-08T05:30Z and SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-08-08T20:00Z. The combined arrival of these CMEs was also detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments at 2024-08-11T21:00Z. This storm may have been further enhanced by a CME arrival detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-08-12T07:44Z which may have been caused by the arrival of the S-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-08-09T08:24Z, the C-type CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 at 2024-08-09T12:53Z, and/or the arrival of the C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-08-09T21:48Z. The arrival of these CMEs may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments at 2024-08-11T21:00Z and 2024-08-12T14:28Z. During the reporting period, simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-08-11T04:44Z, with additional proximity to geosynchronous orbit modeled around 2024-08-11T21:31Z and 2024-08-12T00:31Z (see notifications 20240811-AL-001, 20240811-AL-002, 20240811-AL-004, and 20240811-AL-005).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the geomagnetic activity described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-08-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-08-20T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently nine numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13780 (S08W56), and 13784 (N15W02) were the source for significant flares during the reporting period, including one X-class flare from Active Region 13784 on 2024-08-14, and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity as they continue to traverse the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13777 rotated off of the Earth-facing disk on 2024-08-14 and also exhibited significant flaring during the reporting period, including one X-class flare. This region may be a source of far-sided activity during the outlook period. An unnumbered region currently around S10E90 produced an M5.3 flare on 2024-08-14 and will likely contribute to additional flaring activity from the Earth-facing disk during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and strong levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole centered around N45W10 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-08-16. A minor to strong enhancement in geomagnetic activity is expected around 2024-08-17 due to a C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-08-14T08:23Z associated with an X1.1 flare from Active Region 13784 (N14E03) which peaked at 2024-08-14T06:40Z (see notifications 20240814-AL-001, 20240814-AL-002, and 20240814-AL-005).

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-08-14T08:23Z.

Estimated speed: ~616 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 30 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -4/19 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-08-14T08:23:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, and Lucy (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME may reach Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-16T09:30Z, STEREO A at 2024-08-17T06:07Z, and Lucy at 2024-08-18T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-17T05:10Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-7 (below minor to strong).

## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-08-11T21:31Z.

The activity is associated with the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-08-10T11:55:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240810-AL-004) and with the combined arrival of CME with ID 2024-08-07T03:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240807-AL-001, 20240807-AL-004, 20240808-AL-001) and CME with ID 2024-08-07T14:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240807-AL-004, 20240808-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2024-08-11T21:31:00-MPC-001.

## Notes 

The arrival signature detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 which began with the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-08-10T11:55:00-IPS-001 is still developing and may possibly include the combined arrival of additional CMEs, namely, the S-type CME with ID 2024-08-07T19:36:00-CME-001, the S-type CME with ID 2024-08-08T05:30:00-CME-001, and the S-type CME with ID 2024-08-08T20:00:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240809-AL-001 and 20240810-AL-001), though this analysis is preliminary. This arrival signature is still developing and analysis is ongoing.

Ensemble modeling update on CMEs with IDs 2024-08-07T03:24:00-CME-001 and 2024-08-07T14:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20240807-AL-004). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact STEREO A. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CMEs will reach:
 
- STEREO A between about 2024-08-09T09:43Z and 2024-08-09T16:51Z (average arrival 2024-08-09T12:38Z) for 100% of simulations.
 
Additionally the CMEs are estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2024-08-09T15:21Z and 2024-08-10T00:14Z (average arrival 2024-08-09T18:46Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 59% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 5-7 range (minor to strong).

## Notes:
This 2-CME event (2024-08-07T03:24:00-CME-001 and 2024-08-07T14:24:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at Lucy at 2024-08-11T00:45Z (plus minus 7 hours), Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-09T00:50Z, and Mars at 2024-08-11T02:00Z based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20240807-AL-004).
 
Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.
 
Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 2 X-class flares, 65 M-class flares, 8 O-type CMEs, and 6 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs were predicted to impact missions near Earth:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-08-05T05:53Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-07T20:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor) 
                                       (see notification 20240805-AL-008).
2024-08-05T16:00Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-08T16:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       (see notification 20240805-AL-011).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-07-31T07:12Z   Mars at 2024-08-03T15:00Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-08-02T16:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-02T14:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2024-08-03T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240731-AL-006).
2024-07-31T18:36Z   Mars at 2024-08-03T17:44Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-08-02T10:01Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-03T04:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2024-08-03T08:00Z (glancing blow), Juno at 2024-08-14T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240801-AL-005 ).
2024-08-01T07:24Z   Mars at 2024-08-03T17:44Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-08-02T10:01Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-03T04:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2024-08-03T08:00Z (glancing blow), Juno at 2024-08-14T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notifications 20240801-AL-005 and 20240801-AL-006).
2024-08-02T05:12Z   Mars at 2024-08-05T06:14Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-08-03T14:20Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-08-04T21:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2024-08-05T05:00Z (glancing blow), Juno at 2024-08-15T20:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20240802-AL-003).
2024-08-04T19:00Z   Psyche at 2024-08-14T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240805-AL-001).
2024-08-05T05:53Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-07T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240805-AL-008).
2024-08-05T13:48Z   Mars at 2024-08-08T18:01Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-08-06T16:53Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-08-07T12:00Z (glancing blow), Juno at 2024-08-18T12:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20240805-AL-012).
2024-08-05T16:00Z   Lucy at 2024-08-09T10:01Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-07T17:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240805-AL-011).


Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 6.67 occurred during the synoptic period 2024-08-04T12:00Z-15:00Z (see notifications 20240804-AL-004 and 20240804-AL-005). This significant enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-08-04T13:21Z. The interplanetary shock was likely associated with the arrival of an O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-08-01T07:24Z (see notifications 20240801-AL-005 and 20240801-AL-006). Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-08-04T14:55Z (see notifications 20240804-AL-002 and 20240804-AL-003). The arrival of this CME may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments around 2024-08-04T05:26Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

During the reporting period, there was a solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A (see notification 20240805-AL-010). The flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-08-05T17:26Z. This SEP event was associated with the X1.7 flare from Active Region 13765 (S12W95) which peaked at 2024-08-05T13:40Z (see notifications 20240805-AL-004 and 20240805-AL-005) and the associated O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-08-05T13:48Z (see notification 20240805-AL-012). The energetic proton fluxes of >10 and >100 MeV protons detected at GOES as well as the fluxes of the >15.8 MeV protons channels at SOHO became elevated on 2024-08-05 following the above X1.7 flare but remained below their respective thresholds. The flux of 13-100 MeV of protons at STEREO A decreased below its threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV by the end of 2024-08-05. The fluxes observed at STEREO A, GOES, and SOHO subsided towards background levels through the end of the reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected at STEREO A described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-08-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-08-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently eight numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13780 (S13E35) and 13781 (N13E44) were the source for several significant flares over the second half of the reporting period, including one X-class flare from Active Region 13780, and will likely continue to exhibit notable flaring activity as they continue to traverse the Earth-facing disk. A large cluster of Active Regions (13765, 13766, 13767, 13768, and 13770), which produced multiple significant flares over the reporting period (including the previously mentioned X1.7 class flare from Active Region 13765 on 2024-08-05), has now rotated well beyond the west limb of the Earth-facing disk and may be the source of far-sided activity during the outlook period. Active Regions 13772 (S25W43), 13774 (S07W20) and 13775 (N18W30) which also contributed multiple M-class flares during the reporting period may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity before rotating off of the Earth-facing disk between 2024-08-10 and 2024-08-12. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between below minor and severe levels during the outlook period. Minor enhancements in geomagnetic activity are possible on 2024-08-07 and 2024-08-08 due to predicted glancing blows from an O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-08-05T05:53Z (see notification 20240805-AL-008) and a C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-08-05T16:00Z (see notification 20240805-AL-011). More notably, a moderate to severe enhancement in geomagnetic activity is expected on or around 2024-08-09 due to a combined arrival of two C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-08-07T03:24Z and at 2024-08-07T14:24Z (see notifications 20240807-AL-001 and 20240807-AL-004).
